docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders removed the last major obstacle to a new state budget today, reaching agreement on a plan to spend more than $700 million on school repairs, new housing for the mentally ill, highway projects and a smattering of tax cuts. The deal ends a bitter and protracted stalemate and clears the way for the adoption of a new $73 billion budget that rejects many of the cuts Mr. Pataki had sought in education and health care. It keeps $1.8 billion in a reserve fund to hedge against a downturn in the economy and to make up for revenue lost to future tax cuts. Mr. Pataki had insisted on the reserve fund as part of any final budget agreement.

headline.main: BREAK IN LOGJAM ON ALBANY BUDGET

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki and legislative leaders remove last major obstacle to new state budget, reaching agreement on plan to spend more than $700 million on school repairs, new housing for mentally ill, highway projects and smattering of tax cuts; deal ends bitter and protracted stalemate and clears way for adoption of new $73 billion budget that rejects many of cuts Pataki had sought in education and health care; it keeps $1.8 billion in reserve fund to hedge against downturn in economy and to make up for revenue lost to future tax cuts; photo of Senate Republican majority leader Joseph Bruno and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Deal for Prudential Unit Seems Close to a Give-Away In the next 10 days, Aetna expects to complete what it has called its billion-dollar purchase of Prudential Health Care. But seven months after the agreement was announced, neither side has disclosed the full details. And analysts, left to sort it out for themselves, now say the price is really closer to zero.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente, which said last month that it would pull out of the Northeastern United States, announced details yesterday of its planned departure. Kaiser, a nonprofit company that is the largest United States health maintenance organization, will shut down unprofitable health plans in Massachusetts and Vermont and sell its money-losing plans in New York and Connecticut. The four states account for 558,000 of Kaiser's 8.5 million members. Kaiser, based in Oakland, Calif., said it had agreed to sell its New York business, which has 270,000 members, to Capital District Physicians' Health Plan and its Connecticut H.M.O., which has more than 50,000 members, to Connecticare Inc. Kaiser declined to give the terms of the sales.

headline.main: KAISER PROVIDES DETAILS OF DEPARTURE FROM NORTHEAST

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans in the House put down their marker today in the debate over how to allocate projected Federal budget surpluses, passing the largest tax cut in nearly two decades despite a veto threat from President Clinton. The Republican plan, which would cut taxes by $792 billion over the next decade, passed on a largely party line vote of 223 to 208. Four Republicans voted against it and six Democrats voted in favor.

headline.main: REPUBLICANS PASS BIG TAX CUT TO SET STAGE FOR DEBATE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Congressional Budget Office said today that President Clinton had grossly underestimated the cost of his proposal for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs. Dan L. Crippen, director of the budget office, also told Congress that Mr. Clinton had overstated the savings that could be achieved by his proposals to redesign Medicare and encourage competition in the traditional fee-for-service program.

headline.main: Budget Office Says Clinton Underestimated Cost of Drug Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: After a day of frantic arm-twisting and deal-making, Republican leaders in the House took a big step toward salvaging their cherished tax-cutting bill early today, winning a critical procedural vote rewriting the legislation to quell a revolt by party moderates. Prospects for passage of the $792 billion tax cut improved substantially after Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois and other senior Republicans pressured, cajoled and finally made a deal with about a dozen moderates who said the tax cut was too big and left too little money for debt reduction and domestic spending.

headline.main: Concessions by G.O.P. Leaders Breathe Life Into Tax-Cut Plan

docs.abstract: House Republican Leaders, scrambling to salvage $792 billion tax cut, win key procedural vote on rules governing debate, 219-208, after rewriting bill to quell revolt by party moderates; agree to tie phased 10 percent cut in personal income tax rates to success in reducing national debt; Senate Finance Committee approves $778 billion tax cut package with features different from House bill; Pres Clinton again threatens to veto either version, news conference; pledges to work with both parties for smaller tax cut; photo (M)
